instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no ppbus no power
threads.message:
got this macbook with 20v 0.23amp stable on my digital charger
0v on ppbus but not shorted. i didnt see any short on board. 
just notice that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is abit overheating. tried to replace it but still 0v on ppbus.
tried removed <RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR> then i measure <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> is around 9-10v only.

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no ppbus no power
threads.message: Tell us if you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at least.

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no ppbus no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 93144, member: 682"]
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
[/QUOTE]
oops sorry, yes  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present and stable

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no ppbus no power
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>?
Did you test with charged battery?

Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Be sure to use original 87/96W charger.

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no ppbus no power
threads.message:
sorry this solved already, i didnt mentioned that after i replaced <DIODE>D9602</DIODE> 
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is overheating can see on my thermal cam. 
i replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor board. after i replace
theres no overheating on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> but still cannot on. 
so thinking that <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is different. 
after i replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from my <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor board can on already.. 
[USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] thanks man for always helping me. cheers!
